If the two parties want to move forward with the debate, I could try to word a resolution/broker a compromise on the resolution that would be acceptable to both sides. A simple resolution would probably not do it, but maybe something like this:
 
 The intial spread of AIDS and growth to epidemic proportions was the result of intentional actions within the gay community and could have been avoided if the gay community had changed their behavior.
 
 A few things to note (since I don't want anybody to agree and then feel that it was a trick resolution):
 
 1. The "intentional actions" need not necessarily have been motivated specifically at spreading the aids virus....the resolution does NOt suggest that aids was ever spread on purpose by anybody
 2. There is a certain amount of "could have been" and conjecture in the second part of the resolution. 
 3. The resolution assumes that aids is an epidemic. This is critical to the resolution, so if either participant has trouble with the use of the term "epidemic", changes would have to be made.

 The grammatically incorrect phrase, "Aristotle golden mean", I corrected to "Aristotle's golden mean". https://teach.lanecc.edu/lugenbehld/201/handouts/Golden%20Mean.htm
 Aristotle lived in Greece (384-322 BC). In his book Nicomachaean Ethics, he outlines what he also calls "the doctrine of the mean." What he has to say here is very similar in many ways to the views of Confucius, and he develops at length how this doctrine applies to determining what course of action is right in a number of different situations.
 
 So it's not Napoleon's golden mean, or Confucius's golden mean, but Aristotle's.
